data.session_title: Broadcast track: 30 story ideas that work in any market
data.speakers: Dan Krauth, WABC-TV; Cierra Putman, WTHR; Mallory Sofastaii, WMAR-2 News Baltimore; Katie Wilcox, 12News
data.description: Where to search for stories in your market - tried and true, in-depth and quick turn, with consumer ideas too.

data.session_title: Climate on the record: Crafting investigations with legal documents
data.speakers: Audrey Brown, San Francisco Public Press; Nina Elkadi, Sentient; Jennifer Hijazi, Bloomberg Law; Luis Joel Méndez González, Centro de Periodismo Investigativo
data.description: Covering the story of the climate crisis is so much more than chasing heat waves, oil spills, and sea level rise. Often, the most crucial stories about global warming and its effects on communities are embedded in dockets, spreadsheets, permits, and financial records. This panel will explore how to harness records, legal documents, and data to tell off-the-beaten-path climate stories.

data.session_title: How nonprofit foundations are funding local investigative journalism
data.speakers: Vanessa Bechtel, Ventura County Community Foundation; Tony Biasotti, Ventura County Star; Mauricio Palma, Silicon Valley Community Foundation; Tracie Powell, The Pivot Fund
data.description: How does a newsroom with only eight news reporters have a two-person dedicated investigative team? Are nonprofit foundations, even those that don't typically fund journalism, the answer to dwindling revenue and corporate support for investigative reporting? Can this funding model succeed in communities without deep-pocketed donors and foundations? We will tackle these questions and more with a panel that includes journalists as well as representatives of foundations both large and small that are on the cutting edge of nonprofit funding of investigative journalism.

data.session_title: How to use Census data to power your stories — from quick turns to investigations
data.speakers: Susie Neilson, The San Francisco Chronicle
data.description:
Have you ever wondered how many people in your county make $100,000 or more per year? How about the number of people who were born in Ukraine, or the neighborhood with the largest number of Black homeowners? In this hands-on session, you will learn how to answer these types of questions by downloading and analyzing data from data.census.gov, the official web platform of the U.S. Census Bureau that houses its most popular surveys and programs. You’ll come away with a new skill you can use on a wide range of stories, from quick turnarounds to deep-dive investigations. Best of all: no coding required. 

This session is good for: all levels of experience. Attendees will need to bring their own laptops (preferably no tablets) for the training.

data.session_title: Investigating the wild world of sports
data.speakers: Kenny Jacoby, USA TODAY; David Purdum & Elaine Teng, ESPN; Yami Virgin, KABB WOAI
data.description: From sports betting to labor disputes and corruption, the sports world is ripe for investigation. Come to this panel to hear from journalists who have covered a wide range of topics in the sector to learn how to turn your investigative lens to this industry.

data.session_title: Investigative reporting in rural America
data.speakers: Ilana Newman, The Daily Yonder; Molly Parker, Southern Illinois; Julia Rendleman, Southern Illinois University
data.description:
Rural communities across the country are shrinking, but what happens when a place nearly empties out? Over the past year, we’ve focused our reporting in Alexander County, Illinois, at the confluence of the Ohio and Mississippi rivers—a place The Wall Street Journal declared the fastest-shrinking in America after the 2020 Census. But it’s not alone. Much of rural America is at a crossroads, caught between economic struggles and political uncertainty, trying to figure out how to survive while pushing back against national narratives that often miss the full picture.

This session will challenge the idea that rural places are just sad, dying communities. We’ll talk about how to highlight voices of strength and resilience while also tackling the policies shaping these places in unique ways. Some issues, like food deserts and child care, hit both urban and rural areas, but the challenges are steeper when funding is limited and people and resources are more spread out.

We’ll also dig into underreported issues—farming, forestry, and the role of education from preschool to universities—that serve as lifelines for rural communities. And we’ll look at what’s at stake with policy shifts under a second Trump administration. Just as important, we’ll talk about how to cover all of this with the balance and nuance rural people deserve. That includes working with student reporters and regional universities to help fill news deserts, and how big media companies can partner with local reporters to move beyond clichés and get a real understanding of rural life on the inside.

data.session_title: Records for covering education, and overcoming FERPA denials
data.speakers: David  Cuillier & Sydney Sims, University of Florida / Brechner Freedom of Information Project; Matt Topic, Loevy + Loevy; Patrick Wall, The Times-Picayune | Advocate
data.description: This session provides great records for investigating K-12 and higher education – some classics and some you might not have run across. Then, experts provide tips for wrangling them out of officials’ grubbies by overcoming common denials, particularly FERPA.

data.session_title: Reflecting on 50 years of investigations
data.speakers: Brant Houston, University of Illinois at Urba; Jim Neff, Oregon Journalism Project; Cheryl Phillips, Big Local News at Stanford University; Lea Thompson, Retired - NBC News ; Cheryl W. Thompson, NPR
data.description: Join us for a thought-provoking conversation that celebrates IRE and the evolution of investigative journalism over the past five decades. This session will explore key themes such as the dynamics of the reporter-editor relationship, the impact of collaborative projects across multiple newsrooms, and the growing role of university and international partnerships in investigative work. Panelists will share their insights on how these collaborations have enriched journalism and enhanced the quality of investigations. Attendees can expect a rich discussion filled with valuable lessons, historical perspectives, and visions for the future of investigative reporting.

data.session_title: Broadcast track: How to get investigative content / I-team on air more without diluting your brand
data.speakers: Lindsey Basye, Atlanta News First - WANF; Natalia Martinez, GRAY TV; Julie Watts, CBS News California

data.session_title: Filing a better FOIA request
data.speakers: Josh Eidelson, Bloomberg News; Marta Jewson, The Lens; Suzy Khimm, NBC News
data.description:
This workshop will show you how to increase your chances of receiving records that reveal significant new information to help advance your story.

Who and what can help identify the records you should ask for in the first place? And how can you make it more likely that you’ll receive a useful response? We will look at strategies for formulating and following up on public records requests — treating them as a distinct reporting task, often requiring interviews and other digging to help pinpoint what records could be most helpful to ask for, and relationship-building to successfully shake them loose. We will also examine how to make the most of records that you receive to help find more stories and potential sources – people can lead us to records, and records can lead us to people.

data.session_title: From the outside, looking in: Covering communities and topics you are not part of
data.speakers: Natalia Alamdari, Flatwater Free Press; Hannah  Critchfield, Tampa Bay Times; Albert Serna, Los Angeles Center for Investigative Journalism; Connor Sheets, The Los Angeles Times; Omar Waheed, Madison365
data.description: Investigative reporters are often asked to cover topics that impact or intersect with communities they are not part of. So, how do you build trust, report equitably, and communicate sincerely about your desire to help? This panel discussion will go over ways to connect with communities to build trust, cultivate sources and create open lines of communication.

data.session_title: Investigations following breaking news
data.speakers: Joey Flechas, The Boston Globe; Mauricio Peña, Borderless Magazine; Anne Ryman, ABC15 Arizona; Walter Smith Randolph, CBS News New York
data.description: The best investigations deftly combine narrative in the "day two" story after breaking news as more information may trickle out. We chat about using the tools of storytelling to make people and policymakers care about harms, wrongdoing and matters of accountability. We'll give an overview of how to report, write, structure and edit the story in the days and weeks after news breaks and unpack the challenges that even longtime reporters and editors struggle with along the way.

data.session_title: Managing the investigation
data.speakers: Cindy Galli, Independent journalist; Andrea Gallo, The Times-Picayune | The Advocate; Kevin Keeshan, NBC Universal Local; Michael Sallah, Pittsburgh Post-Gazette
data.description: Editing a data-driven or investigative story comes with its own challenges. We'll talk about how to manage quick-turn and enterprise projects. Topics include vetting ideas, time management and keeping channels of communication open inside the newsroom. We'll also look at a litmus test for whether a story is worth further investigation.

data.session_title: Pitching a great investigative project
data.speakers: Nicole Dungca, The Washington Post; Matt Krupnick, Independent journalist; Brian Rosenthal, The New York Times; Brad Schrade, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution; Claudia Vargas, NBC10 Philadelphia
data.description:
The most important step in launching an investigation is focusing on the idea. What do you investigate?  How do you get there?
What are the best ways to vet an idea?
There is both a how to:  what is the process organizations  use to brainstorm or pitch investigative proposals and
how do they evaluate ideas to move ahead with the best:

data.session_title: What is (and isn't) a good fit for AI-assisted journalism?
data.speakers: Juliana Castro Varón, New York Times; Dylan Freedman, The New York Times
data.description: This session details how the New York Times A.I. Initiatives team integrates product design, machine learning, and editorial expertise to help create stories with A.I. and build tools for investigative journalism. We will present real-world examples of how the industry uses machine learning in investigative reporting, demonstrate our tools, and help reporters triage what is a good fit for A.I. – and what isn't. The presentation will conclude with an open discussion.

data.session_title: Are you afraid of the AI?
data.speakers: Marissa Evans, Investigative Project on Race and Equity; Mark Greenblatt, Howard Center for Investigative Journalism, Arizona State University; Liz Lucas, Missouri School of Journalism
data.description: Artificial intelligence –– for better or worse –– is here to stay and its influence on newsgathering, news cycles, and the future of journalism is only growing. This panel will focus on helping journalists understand AI 101 and the opportunities that AI is creating for journalists. This is a no holds barred, no dumb questions discussion that features journalists who are creating and building projects using AI and using it to make their jobs easier.

data.session_title: Broadcast track: Here's the data, where's the story?
data.speakers: David Barer, KXAN News; Lori Jane Gliha, Scripps News; John Kelly, CBS News
data.description: How do you get from “I got the data” to TV? Three broadcast journalists walk you through every step from getting the data to transforming what you find into an interesting TV story.

data.session_title: Funding the future of investigative journalism
data.speakers: Eric Ferrero, Fund for Investigative Journalism; Jane Sasseen, McGraw Center for Business Journalism; Jackie Stenson, USC Annenberg Center for Health Journalism
data.description: Tips and tricks from some of the leading journalism foundations on applying to grants. Do's and don'ts of writing an application, creating a budget, being realistic about your impact and more.

data.session_title: How to find data on Indigenous communities and what to do when it doesn't exist
data.speakers: Dana Hedgpeth, The Washington Post; Mary Hudetz, ProPublica; Dianna Hunt, ICT (formerly Indian Country Today)
data.description: When we look at the data on Indigenous peoples, including American Indians and Alaska Natives, we are able to see that there is a substantial amount of data from health care to education undercounted and misclassified, often cited as a lack of uniformity on how it's collected over generations by governments. We'll talk about best practices as Indigenous data sovereignty, the idea that Indigenous Peoples should decide how to collect, own, and use their own data, globally gains traction.

data.session_title: Investigating for-profit health care
data.speakers: Phil Barber, Santa Rosa Press Democrat ; Mary Fricker, RepoWatch; Elizabeth Koh, The Boston Globe; Hannah Levintova, Mother Jones/ Center for Investigative Reporting; Jessica Silver-Greenberg, The New York Times; Katie  Thomas, New York Times
data.description: Health care is a wildly profitable business, accounting for nearly 20 percent of the American economy. In your community there may be companies putting revenue before care. Our panelists have years of experience covering a range of companies, including for-profit (and even so-called non-profit) hospital systems, clinics, behavioral hospitals, elder care facilities like assisted living and memory care, and pharmaceutical firms. We will show you how to find these stories and how to report them out, with lists of story ideas, sources, how to get data and how to find experts who can propose solutions.

data.session_title: Investigating war crimes in an active, sealed-off war zone
data.speakers: Yahya Abou-Ghazala, CNN; Kavitha Chekuru, Independent journalist; Hoda Osman, Arab Reporters for Investigative Journalism (ARIJ); Maryam Saleh, Rest of World
data.description: In this panel, journalists will share their experience producing collaborative investigations between journalists inside Gaza and their counterparts outside the war zone. Join this session to learn strategies that journalists can use for verifying on-the-ground critical reporting, and to learn from the panelists' experience covering the war in Gaza.

data.session_title: Tracking the hundreds of lawsuits filed against the Trump administration
data.speakers: Cam Baker, The New York Times; Seamus Hughes, Court Watch
data.description: We combined scraping, Google Sheets, Slack alerts, the knowledge of an experienced legal reporter and other resources to track the hundreds of lawsuits filed against the Trump administration so far. In this session, we’ll review how we carried out a large-scale reporting project involving the courts.

data.session_title: When government data disappears: How to cross-check, preserve, and investigate
data.speakers: Jay Hunter, Hunter Index; Jason Leopold, Bloomberg News; Anna Massoglia, Influence Brief; Michael Nolan, Sunlight Research Center
data.description: From vanishing government websites to manipulated economic data, journalists are facing increasing challenges in verifying official information. This session will cover how to investigate missing or altered government records and ensure the integrity of public-interest reporting. Panelists will discuss how to verify whether government data has been changed or removed, how to find alternative sources when public records disappear, and how to archive and preserve crucial datasets before they become inaccessible. This session is designed for journalists who rely on public records, government websites, or large datasets and need to ensure their information remains reliable and available.

data.session_title: Beyond the Ivies: Major higher ed stories you shouldn’t miss
data.speakers: Meredith Kolodner, The Hechinger Report; Arionne Nettles, Florida A&M University; Chris Quintana, USA TODAY Network
data.description: Universities around the U.S. are facing political scrutiny at federal, state and local levels—affecting nearly every beat in your newsroom. Amid the spotlight on budget cuts and anti-DEI laws, are you missing the stories that may impact your community the most? Come to this panel to learn about the under-covered stories in higher education and how to cover them on your beat. Your viewers, readers and listeners might be shocked to know what's happening at colleges and universities nationwide. This session is sponsored by Lumina Foundation. IRE retains control of content, including the topic and speaker selection, for all conference sessions.

data.session_title: Broadcast track: Make it memorable! Storytelling in investigations
data.speakers: A.J. Lagoe, KARE-TV/TEGNA; Cristin Severance, WRAL; Chris Vanderveen, KUSA-TV
data.description: What makes a broadcast investigation not just good, but unforgettable? This panel dives into the craft and storytelling techniques that elevate powerful broadcast investigations. Learn how to shape complex reporting into stories that resonate and stay with viewers.

data.session_title: Following the anti-trans federal actions
data.speakers: Gisselle Medina, Fresnoland; Eesha Pendharkar, States Newsroom; Lewis Raven Wallace, Interrupting Criminalization; Adam Rhodes, IRE & NICAR
data.description: As Republican administrations continue attacks on trans people across the country in health care, education, military service and behind bars, reporters need to be ready to cover this far reaching topic with accuracy, nuance, and care. Come to this session to hear how to tackle these important stories, how to push back on rhetoric and euphemism, and how to tell honest, truthful stories about trans people in your communities.

data.session_title: From text to TV (and everything in between): How investigative journalists have adapted over the years
data.speakers: Neal Bennett , The E.W. Scripps Company; Laura Frank, Colorado News Collaborative (COLab); Jared Kofsky, ABC News; Anne Ryman, ABC15 Arizona; Olive Talley, Olive Talley Productions LLC
data.description: This moderated conversation will explore the challenges and triumphs that journalists face when they're ready (or forced) to pivot. Panelists will share personal anecdotes that illustrate their experiences, providing insight into the strategies they employ to remain relevant and impactful in an industry marked by rapid change. You'll walk away with practical advice and insights that can benefit aspiring and seasoned journalists alike.

data.session_title: Investigating climate change
data.speakers: Michael Biesecker, Associated Press; Allison Prang, Freelance journalist; Tracy Wholf, CBS News and Stations
data.description: Learn how to execute climate reporting across any beat in the newsroom, explore how to turn policy and data analysis into visual investigations, and come away with different story ideas to cover climate issues at the national, state and local levels. We'll look at how to cover potential solutions to fight climate change, as well as the obstacles society is facing in trying to decarbonize. Panelists will discuss the current challenges to climate reporting and how to overcome the issue of disappearing datasets to support environmental investigations.

data.session_title: Navigating record requests within the criminal legal system
data.speakers: Fola Akinnibi, Bloomberg News; Laura Bennett , The Center for Just Journalism; Ethan Corey, The Appeal; Paige Pfleger, WPLN News and ProPublica
data.description: Impactful reporting on the criminal justice system hinges on a journalist’s ability to access detailed information about the inner workings of that system. This information has always been hard to come by and is only growing more so during a time of declining transparency. In this panel, attendees will have the opportunity to learn from their peers who are experts in obtaining data, court records, and public records from criminal justice agencies and using that information to tell powerful stories about everything from fatal police chases to jail deaths. The panelists will offer concrete recommendations for obtaining records and story ideas worth investigating in attendees' own communities.

data.session_title: Uncovering hope in hard times: How to strengthen your investigation with a solutions mindset
data.speakers: Ashley Clarke, ProPublica; John Diedrich, Milwaukee Journal Sentinel | Marquette University; Michelle Levander, USC Annenberg Center for Health Journalism; Christiaan Mader, The Current; Raquel Rutledge, The Examination
data.description: Are solutions to the wrongdoings exposed in your investigations often an afterthought? We’ll talk about how reporting out potential solutions at the outset – and connecting early and often in creative ways with those most affected by the issues – will not only increase the odds your stories will prompt real change, but will connect you more deeply to sources with differing viewpoints. (Not easy to do in today's world.) And that's not all! We’ll also show you how this framing can help you build bridges to audiences you’ve struggled to reach.

data.session_title: Using open source tools to localize national data
data.speakers: Nicole Lewis, The Marshall Project; Aaron Mendelson, The Trace; Cheryl Phillips, Big Local News at Stanford University; Samantha Sunne, Independent Journalist
data.description: There are a number of national newsrooms and industry organizations that are designing products to support journalists who want to localize various datasets for maximum accountability and community impact. We will gather a few leaders in this space to demo the products they’ve created for local journalists, which include embeddable data graphics, help and research desks, record crowdsourcing and archiving projects, and more.

data.session_title: Audio track: Bringing data and public records to life in audio
data.speakers: Jess Clark, Kentucky Center for Investigative Reporting; Huo Jingnan, NPR; Sukey Lewis, KQED; Halle Parker, Verite News
data.description: The data that journalists work with is often messy, and they rarely provide us with clear-cut or sweeping conclusions. How can we bring complicated numbers, especially in finance and science, to the listeners in a way that makes sense? How can we unearth public recordings that are often never heard? Panelists will share their strategies for breaking down complex concepts, finding the human stories behind the data, and crafting compelling audio narratives with public records.

data.session_title: Broadcast track: From boring to blockbuster: Tricks and tools to up your visual game
data.speakers: Luke Carter, WANF-TV; Anna Hewson, 9NEWS; Tony Kovaleski, Denver7 News; Joshua Saunders, KSAT-TV
data.description: In this panel, learn about how to make the non-visual story come to life for TV: color grading, editing, After Effects, framing interviews, etc.

data.session_title: Covering serial murder, cold cases and missing and unidentified persons
data.speakers: Peter Barth, Bellingcat; Rocío Gallegos, La Verdad Juarez; Lise Olsen, Texas Observer
data.description: Writing about unsolved and complex cases involving missing and murdered people and their killers presents unique challenges. Learn how to use the latest OSINT techniques, obscure archives and intense interviews to dive into these tough stories in the United States - and Mexico.

data.session_title: Deep dive: Cultivating sources
data.speakers: Olivia Carville, Bloomberg; Corey Johnson, ProPublica
data.description: When it comes to developing and maintaining sources—an intimate, demanding, all-consuming process—two of the best are Olivia Carville and Corey Johnson, reporters who know how to get inside major companies and government agencies, or schools, prisons and churches. They’ll talk about how their backgrounds have helped guide them in cultivating sources with compassion; the art of the cold call; taking care with victims of trauma; building trust; keeping sources on-side; and the good that can come from leaning into your humanity.

data.session_title: Finding a needle in a haystack: How to manage document-heavy investigations
data.speakers: Andrei Baiu & Amairany Martinez & Chris Miles & Joanne Sprague, Everlaw
data.description:
Searching for relevant evidence for a story through a never-ending pile of documents, legal forms, contracts, emails, videos, or cell phone data can be taxing and time-consuming, even for the best investigative teams out there. 

The team at Everlaw will demonstrate their tools to help with automatic transcription of audio and video (think bodycam footage, depositions, interview recordings), making documents text-searchable through optical character recognition, file management tools (like search, labeling, AI summaries), analysis tools (like data viz and topic clustering), and story-building tools (drafting, citations, and AI writing assistance). They'll show how newsrooms like the San Francisco Chronicle, ProPublica and Fast Company uncover key information using their tool.

You'll also learn about Everlaw’s free offering for journalists, which includes unlimited users, training and support at no extra cost.

data.session_title: Investigating Trump
data.speakers: Hannah  Allam, ProPublica; Josh Dawsey, The Wall Street Journal; Josh Meyer, USA TODAY Network; Ellen Nakashima, The Washington Post
data.description: On this panel, journalists will discuss how to investigate Trump in such turbulent times, where the administration and even the public seem so adversarial to their job. Learn how to investigate the current administration in your city or town.

data.session_title: Investigating hunger
data.speakers: Ayurella Horn-Muller, Grist; Brett Murphy, ProPublica; Deborah Nelson, University of Maryland; Thin Lei Win, Lighthouse Reports
data.description: Food insecurity in the U.S. is at the highest level in a decade with nearly 14% of households - 47 million people -- struggling to put meals on the table. Nearly 300 million face hunger crises worldwide. This panel will offer ideas, sources, tools and techniques for investigating the political, corporate and climate forces that are driving up hunger locally and globally.

data.session_title: Real estate investigations: Covering the government, private sector and private equity sectors
data.speakers: Robert Benincasa, NPR; Gordon Russell, The Boston Globe; Caitlin Thompson, Honolulu Civil Beat
data.description: Learn how public records and data about real estate can fuel your investigations of companies and agencies operating in the home mortgage and commercial property spaces. From foreclosures and contracts to federal programs covering veterans, to private equity transactions that can compromise public services, we’ll decode the jargon, documents and data available for real estate investigations.

data.session_title: 60 opioid settlement (and other public health) stories in 60 minutes!
data.speakers: Drew Hawkins, Gulf States Newsroom; Ed Mahon, Spotlight PA; Aneri Pattani, KFF Health News
data.description: This fast-paced, interactive session will share 30 opioid settlement story ideas and  30 public health reporting angles on other overlooked and urgent issues. You’ll get practical tips on covering high-volume medical marijuana doctors, controversial incarceration programs, and the human toll of the Trump administration’s funding cuts. Whether on a daily deadline or digging into a months-long investigation, you’ll leave with fresh ideas and tools to go deeper.

data.session_title: Broadcast track: Sourcing in this new "no comment" world
data.speakers: Daniela Molina, InvestigateTV/Gray Media; Dannah Sauer, WVUE-TV; Phil Williams, WTVF-TV
data.description: Can't get anyone to talk to you on the record? Reaching out for accountability interviews and getting "no comment"...or worse, no response at all? We'll discuss creative ways to make sure your reporting is well-rounded, even if you can't get people to talk to you on camera.

data.session_title: Covering corporate behavior: What they do (not what they say) and their big plans for the future
data.speakers: David Armiak, Center for Media and Democracy; Arlene Martinez, Good Jobs First; Nadine Sebai, Freelance
data.description: Companies are great spinning stories that present themselves as heroes. But behind the scenes, their behavior often fails to mirror that reality. Learn how to scour company behavior (on deadline!) using the Violation Tracker database to explore the backgrounds of companies across 450 federal, state, and local regulatory agencies (including EPA, OSHA, state attorneys general offices, etc). And beyond the regulatory landscape — in many agencies rapidly degrading under the new administration – learn how sources and other records can help expose misconduct. Also get info on the states' version of Project 2025, being pushed by the American Legislative Exchange Council (ALEC). Similar to the national Project 2025, the states-level version seeks to, among other things, empower fossil fuel companies, undermine public education, repress voting rights, and more. Journalists are great at exposing the misbehavior of elected officials – walk away with tips on applying that same sharp scrutiny to company leaders. This session is sponsored by Bloomberg. IRE retains control of content, including the topic and speaker selection, for all conference sessions.

data.session_title: Freelancers: Create entrepreneurship systems that work for you
data.speakers: Ann Marie Awad, Institute for Independent Journalists; Rita Harper, Freelance Photojournalist; Carolina Murriel, Freelance Writer and Journalist
data.description: With mass layoffs and an unstable job market, more journalists are freelancing, out of need or by choice – and many are creating their own newsletters or startup businesses. This session will cover how to create systems that take work off your plate! You’ll see a demo of the Institute for Independent Journalists’ interactive online freelance startup guide, which helps answer the key questions for ramping up a side hustle into a full-time business. Panelists will share tools for setting your rate, networking to find great assignments, building relationships with clients, and juggling multiple projects. Participants will leave the session with a slew of new tools and strategies for becoming an emotionally and financially sustainable freelancer.

data.session_title: Responsibly and creatively reporting on children and teens
data.speakers: Jenn Abelson, Washington Post; Jessica Contrera, The Washington Post; Bennett Haeberle, NBC Chicago, WMAQ-TV; Eli Hager, ProPublica
data.description: Reporting on sources under the age of 18 often requires deep sensitivity, advanced planning and inventive approaches to gathering records. From the child welfare and education systems to the sexual abuse of children by law enforcement to teens in residential treatment facilities and group homes, come learn from a panel of reporters about how to initially approach children and their families as sources; how to make kids feel comfortable in an interview setting; how to navigate issues of consent; how to obtain juvenile court records; where to mine for information on systems charged with caring for kids; and more.

data.session_title: There’s a disability angle on your beat
data.speakers: Emily Hopkins, Mirror Indy; Jennifer LaFleur, UC Berkeley Graduate School of Journalism; Amy Silverman, KJZZ-NPR
data.description: Get real-world examples of reporting that centers the people with disabilities, rather than writing and reporting around them. This session will be packed with tips and insights to help journalists across beats bolster their coverage of disability-related issues and elevate the voices and needs of this key segment of our communities.

data.session_title: Turn your questions into data with an LLM
data.speakers: Diana Dombrowski, Bloomberg Law; Umar Farooq & Gary Harki, Bloomberg Industry Group
data.description:
Learn how journalists at Bloomberg Industry Group used a large language model to turn questions into data as part of an investigation showing that voting rights claims dropped following a recent U.S. Supreme Court decision.

This session is good for people with some experience working with data. Laptops will be provided. You will also need to sign up for a ChatGPT account to participate in the hands-on exercise: https://openai.com/index/chatgpt/

data.session_title: Vetting the great investigative idea
data.speakers: Bob Blau, Bloomberg; Rose Ciotta, Atlanta Journal-Constitution; Ron Nixon, The Associated Press

data.session_title: Behind the story: "Tráileres, trampa para migrantes” (Cargo trucks: A trap for migrants)
data.speakers: Angela Cantador, Latin American Center for Investigative Journalism (CLIP); Martha Olivia López, ; Brenda Medina, International Consortium of Investigative Journalists; Ronny Rojas, Noticias Telemundo
data.description: This panel dives into the challenges, rewards and lessons of the award-winning collaboration between U.S. and Latin American journalists, which investigated deadly migrant smuggling across Mexico using cargo trucks. Come to learn about how to choose the right partners and how to approach and protect your sources(and yourself) in hostile environments. You’ll also learn about useful tools and strategies to uncover cross-border immigration stories and amplify vulnerable voices in this crucial beat.

data.session_title: Bridging the newsroom and the classroom: Tackling big projects with student journalists
data.speakers: Kathy Best & Kathy Best, Howard Center for Investigative Journalism, University of Maryland; Brant Houston, University of Illinois at Urba; Maggie Mulvihill, Boston University College of Communication; Brian Patrick O’Donoghue, University of Alaska Fairbanks
data.description: This session is sponsored by Scripps Howard Fund. IRE retains control of content, including the topic and speaker selection, for all conference sessions.

data.session_title: Broadcast track: Consumer confidential
data.speakers: Leah Dunn, WSB-TV ATLANTA; Justin Gray, WSB-TV; Caresse Jackman, InvestigateTV/Gray Media
data.description: In this panel, you’ll hear from experienced consumer investigative journalists and producers. We’ll explore the various ways you can make your consumer investigations impactful. From knowing when a story is a daily turn or a more involved investigation, to showcasing how the nation’s federal consumer protection agencies directly impact your community. We will also discuss how to incorporate solutions-based journalism in your reports and utilize consumer advisors to help make your investigations stronger.

data.session_title: Covering the F.A.A.
data.speakers: Cary Aspinwall, The Marshall Project; Kate Kelly, New York Times; Peter Robison, Bloomberg News
data.description: Transportation is always a beat moving but the last year has seen an increase of high-profile crashes, delays and gutting of federal agencies with already shortstaffed departments in the aviation industry. Learn from those who have covered this topic soaring on our news feeds while raising serious questions about public safety and the integrity of the Federal Aviation Adminstration.

data.session_title: Disclosing AI: What audiences want and how newsrooms can respond
data.speakers: Joy Mayer, Trusting News
data.description: News consumers want transparency when journalists use artificial intelligence in reporting. Recent survey and interview data from Trusting News shows audiences not only expect AI disclosure but also prefer detailed explanations about how AI was used and which tools were involved. This research also showed audiences are particularly uneasy about AI’s role in data analysis. This session will explore how investigative journalists can meet audience expectations while maintaining trust and credibility. Trusting News will share best practices, newsroom-tested disclosure strategies, and real-world examples of AI transparency in investigative reporting. Attendees will leave with actionable insights on how to effectively communicate AI use, address audience concerns, and ensure human oversight remains central in AI-assisted investigations.

data.session_title: Document crowd competition: 40 ideas in 40 minutes
data.speakers: David  Cuillier & Sydney Sims, University of Florida / Brechner Freedom of Information Project; Christina Jedra, Honolulu Civil Beat
data.description: This session invites attendees to compete for prizes for offering the coolest, most unique public records that every journalist should request. Each person gets one minute to come up to the mic and explain their record. The idea will be entered into a list of the screen, and then at the end attendees vote for their favorite. The top three win fabulous IRE merchandise. The 2024 winners, among 37 ideas offered, were Twitter drafts, public official Spotify wraps, and U Visa certification denials.

data.session_title: Finding the story: Crime stats
data.speakers: Jill Castellano, The Marshall Project; Maia Rosenfeld, ABC
data.description:
There’s a lot of data out there on policing and crime but so much of it is bad for a variety of reasons. In this session we’ll separate the good from the bad and discuss stories just waiting to be written in your community.

Basic knowledge of working with spreadsheets is helpful, but not required. Attendees will need to bring their own laptops (preferably no tablets) for the training.

data.session_title: Income inequality:  A force that is tearing our communities apart
data.speakers: Jeff Ernsthausen, ProPublica; Mary Fricker, RepoWatch; Mary Sanchez, Independent reporter ; James Steele, Reporter, Author, Teacher
data.description: In your community, it’s likely that the wealthy are getting richer, leaving the rest of your community behind. Why? Mainly because laws that used to treat citizens equally now favor the rich. In every community we need to be showing how this Gilded Age threatens our nation. Our panelists have years of experience covering this important issue. They will tell you how to find these stories and how to report them out, with lists of story ideas, sources, how to get data and how to find experts who can propose solutions.

data.session_title: Working with sensitive and hard-to-reach sources
data.speakers: Julie Brown, Miami Herald; Emily Hopkins, Mirror Indy; Judith Matloff, Columbia Graduate School of Journalism; Julie Small, KQED Public Radio; Alissa Zhu, The Baltimore Banner
data.description: A key question in almost every investigation is how to work with potential sources who have vital information – but are reluctant to share it. They may be victims of crimes, incarcerated people, members of marginalized groups, even possible whistleblowers with access to confidential material. How can you earn their trust? And how can you ensure that they are not retraumatized or harmed by helping you? This panel will equip you with the tools to connect with sources in a variety of vulnerable circumstances.

data.session_title: Bolstering local reporting through collaborations with large newsrooms
data.speakers: Sarah Blustain, ProPublica; Ryan Little, The Baltimore Banner; Ron Nixon, The Associated Press; Cheryl Phillips, Big Local News at Stanford University; Adam Playford, The New York Times
data.description:
The outlets represented on this panel all have initiatives designed to support local investigative news. This panel will discuss the different initiatives' aims, approaches, accomplishments, and adversities. Attendees will glean insights into project management techniques and get tips for creating effective, multi-newsroom collaborations. 

This session is sponsored by The New York Times. IRE retains control of content, including the topic and speaker selection, for all conference sessions.

data.session_title: Broadcast track: Collaborating for survival and surviving your collaboration
data.speakers: Jodie Fleischer, Cox Media Group; Cindy Galli, Independent journalist; David Hammer, WWL Louisiana; John Hillkirk, KFF Health News; Kara Kenney, WRTV; Ramon Vargas, The Guardian
data.description: A real honest discussion of the challenges and triumphs of collaborations and how to do it better.

data.session_title: Covering courts: Free tools & strategies to access records and navigate trials
data.speakers: Jeremy Chase, Davis Wright Tremaine LLP; William Palin, Free Law Project; Frank G.  Runyeon, Law360; Emily  Saul, New York Law Journal/ALM
data.description: Legal reporting has never been more critical. Courts are treasure troves of information, but how do you access all those records and proceedings? We’ll explore free tools, techniques and strategies to overcome obstacles and get the story. You’ll learn how to track cases from afar, combine digital tools with courthouse shoe leather reporting, learn legal arguments and hear about coalition-building strategies you can use to gain access to filings and proceedings in person – even when you’re not welcome.

data.session_title: Covering housing authoritatively: How to expose the unseen challenges of renters
data.speakers: Alejandra Cancino, Injustice Watch; Juan Pablo Garnham, Eviction Lab (Princeton University); Cecilia Reyes, Independent journalist
data.description: One in three U.S. residents is a renter, and the proportion is even bigger among communities of color and low-income families. Yet, reporting on the challenges of these communities is often neglected or falls into the same tropes of landlords versus tenants. How can we continue to move forward through data to build investigations, even when it's difficult to find the right sources? During this conversation, panelists will discuss tools for building nuanced investigations that focus on government accountability. They will also talk about the importance of narrative storytelling and human-centered stories.

data.session_title: Deep dive: Working as a team: Lessons from a rockstar reporting duo
data.speakers: Robin McDowell and Margie Mason, Associated Press
data.description: Margie Mason and Robin McDowell have been reporting partners for 20 years, helping produce one epic investigation after another, including “Seafood from Slaves,” which led to numerous arrests, the seizure of ships and the freeing of more than 2,000 people. If journalism has a fledgling heir to Barlett and Steele, it could be Mason and McDowell. They’ll talk about what makes their partnership tick; how they regularly swap hats, even though one revels in the Indiana Jones stuff and the other in Robert Caro-level detail and documentation; and how, through it all, they have never once had a fight.

data.session_title: Heat, floods, cold and fire: Covering the intersection of climate change and incarceration
data.speakers: Keri Blakinger, Houston Chronicle; Alleen Brown, Freelance, Drilled, Eco Files newsletter; Hannah  Riley Fernandez, Center for Just Journalism; Wyatt Stayner, Prison Journalism Project
data.description:
Incarcerated people are among the most vulnerable to climate disasters. From extreme heat and cold to hurricanes and wildfires that force chaotic evacuations—or leave people trapped in harm’s way—the climate crisis is exacerbating what are already dire conditions behind bars.

This panel brings together investigative journalists and editors covering their work on the dangers facing people incarcerated, how climate policy often overlooks incarcerated populations, and the challenges of holding institutions accountable. The panelists will also offer practical guidance on how others can investigate these issues in their own communities—accessing public records, analyzing climate risk data, and centering the voices of incarcerated people and their families.

data.session_title: So you think you want to write a book?
data.speakers: Jennifer Hawes & T. Christian Miller, ProPublica; Jerry Mitchell, Mississippi Today; Cheryl W. Thompson, NPR
data.description: Do you have an investigative project you'd like to turn into a book? Are you searching for book ideas and mystified by the world of agents and advances? These reporters-turned-authors share their best advice on developing and selling a book proposal, financing the reporting and writing (we promise brass tacks!), and exploring options like indie publishers, podcasts, and docuseries.

data.session_title: Web scraping with Python
data.speakers: Janelle O'Dea, Illinois Answers Project
data.description:
If you need data that's trapped on a website, writing some code to scrape the page could be your solution. This entry-level class will show you how to use the Python programming language to harvest data from a website into a data file. We'll introduce you to the command line and show you how to write enough code to fetch and parse content on the web.

This class is programming for beginners. Some basic familiarity with Python and HTML is helpful but not required. You must bring your own laptop (no tablets) to this training, and you'll need a Google account.

data.session_title: Beyond the investigation: Managing stress, safety & mental wellness
data.speakers: Marissa Evans, Investigative Project on Race and Equity; Marla Jones-Newman, The Center for Investigative Reporting; Gonzalo  Magaña, ABC10/TEGNA ; Judith Matloff, Columbia Graduate School of Journalism; Naseem Miller, The Journalist's Resource; Zack Newman, Freelance investigative data journalist
data.description:
Let’s be honest, investigative journalism can take a serious toll. Long hours, emotionally difficult topics, graphic content, public scrutiny, and even safety threats — both online and in person — can contribute to burnout, anxiety, depression, and PTSD. And for newsroom leaders, managers, and editors, the responsibility extends beyond just the stories, it includes caring for the people who report them. Join this candid conversation to learn more about practical strategies for managing stress, setting healthy boundaries, supporting team members, and building safer, more sustainable newsroom cultures.

NOTE: This session will not be recorded, so participants may engage freely (but respectfully) regarding personal situations.

data.session_title: Broadcast track: "I don't watch TV news" How to get your content in front of the next generation of viewers
data.speakers: Ben Bradley, WGN-TV Chicago; Levi Ismail, WTVF NewsChannel 5; Ashlyn Lipori-Russie, Ask Ashlyn; Ted Oberg, News4 NBC Washington
data.description: We know you’ve been told, ‘we need to focus on our younger demos, they’re not watching tv.’  But they are watching news. We’ll prove it to you, give you solutions to stop wasting time and start getting in front of as many people as possible. We’ll (try to) absolve you of your guilt about ‘monetization’ and definitely discuss whether dancing anchor videos are good brand builders for investigative reporters. We guarantee there is something you haven’t heard in this hour, hopefully more than one thing! Come with questions.

data.session_title: Data analysis with Python
data.speakers: Sandra Fish, Independent data journalist
data.description:
In this session, you'll learn how to analyze data using the popular Python data analysis library pandas. You'll learn about the benefits of scripting your data projects and enough syntax to load, sort, filter and group a data set.

This class is good for: People who are comfortable working with data in spreadsheets or SQL and want to make the leap to programming. You must bring your own laptop (no tablets) to this training, and you'll need a Google account.

data.session_title: Exemption redemption: How to overcome public records exemptions
data.speakers: David  Cuillier, University of Florida / Brechner Freedom of Information Project; Gunita Singh, Reporters Committee for Freedrom of the Press; Matt Topic, Loevy + Loevy
data.description: This session provides practical tips for how to overcome the most common exemptions in public record laws, including attorney-client, deliberative process, privacy, trade secrets, investigatory, vague/unduly burdensome, and other legal barriers such as FERPA and HIPAA. Bring up others and stump the experts!

data.session_title: How to pivot from the newsroom: Reinventing yourself without losing your investigative edge
data.speakers: Elaine Aradillas, independent journalist; Eric Ferrero, Fund for Investigative Journalism; Greg Lee, Loyola University New Orleans; Alain Stephens, Independent journalist
data.description: Burnout, layoffs, or a desire for new challenges can push investigative reporters to consider career pivots—but leaving the newsroom doesn’t mean leaving your skills behind. This session explores how to transform your expertise into new careers, from freelancing and book writing to producing documentaries.

data.session_title: Showcase: Reporters in peril over the decades
data.speakers: Richard Behar, Forbes magazine; Rocío Gallegos, La Verdad Juarez; Lise Olsen, Texas Observer; John Quiñones, ABC News; Martin Reynolds, Maynard Institute
data.description: This panel will explore notable cases, from the Arizona Project to the Chauncey Bailey Project, as well as the real, life-threatening work that journalists continue to do. Panelists will examine how the landscape of reporting has evolved while the dangers persist. After all, you can silence the journalist, but the story will live on.

data.session_title: The art of the business investigation
data.speakers: Polly Mosendz, Bloomberg News; Christopher Weaver, The Wall Street Journal; Scott Zamost, CNBC
data.description: From getting CEOs to talk to deep diving into a company, a business investigation has its own sets of challenges. You'll hear from veteran print and broadcast journalists on navigating these challenges and how to turn a tip into a compelling corporate investigation. We will cover how to source up at companies you cover, especially those with NDAs, the aggressive nature of PR in business investigations and how to keep your cool when they are yelling at you and calling your editor as well as front running stories with press releases. This session is sponsored by Bloomberg. IRE retains control of content, including the topic and speaker selection, for all conference sessions.

data.session_title: The reporter and editor relationship
data.speakers: Matt Apuzzo, The New York Times; Shawn McIntosh, Retired, Atlanta Journal-Constitution; Elaine Teng & Tisha Thompson, ESPN
data.description: How do you get the most out of the best editors? How do you manage to improve your writing even with the less-than-best editors? We'll offer practical tips about enduring the difficult edit, overcoming tension, and getting past the struggles that lead to "good enough."

data.session_title: Tracking right-wing influencers and movements
data.speakers: David Armiak, Center for Media and Democracy; Robert Downen, Texas Monthly; Kyle Spencer, The Pro-Democracy Information Lab/Reporting Right
data.description: The 2024 presidential election made it clear: The far right is no longer just ascendant -- it's the beating heart of the Republican Party, and will be a fixture of our politics and newsrooms for years to come. This session will provide a crash course on some of the movement's many factions, including right-wing campus groups, extremist influencers, Christian nationalist lawmakers, and the secretive networks and billionaires fueling them. Panelists will cover the basics -- how to stay safe online, for instance -- while also providing an overview of the ideologies and tactics already reshaping American democracy and politics at every level.

data.session_title: Audio track: Investigative stories you can feel: Engaging audience through voices
data.speakers: Najib Aminy, Reveal; Fernanda Echavarri, Futuro Media / Futuro Studios / Latino USA ; Will James, KUOW; Anna Sussman, Snap Studios at KQED
data.description: Not all investigative journalism has to be dense to be impactful. This panel explores how to craft stories that reveal deep truths while keeping the audience engaged and not overwhelmed. Panelists discuss the art of navigating liminal spaces—storytelling that exists as both hard-hitting exposés and character based narratives—to find nuance, and humanity.

data.session_title: Broadcast track: The 10 most important lessons I've learned
data.speakers: Eric Flack, WUSA9; Bigad Shaban, NBC Bay Area; Joce Sterman, InvestigateTV/Gray Media
data.description: Investigative journalism is hard. We feel your pain. Sometimes you just need a little motivation, some laughs and a bit of advice gained from the real-life mistakes & lessons from people who’ve been there and survived pretty much anything you can imagine in this business. Join us for IRE Summer School – it’s like regular school, but better - more laid back...and taught by three investigative journalists ready to pass along some of the educational instructions they might have missed the first time around.

data.session_title: Deep dive: Two reporters talk writing
data.speakers: Pamela Colloff, ProPublica; Hannah  Dreier, The New York Times
data.description: Pamela Colloff and Hannah Dreier are two of investigative journalism’s greatest writers. Their stories are both epic and intimate. They seem always to be in just the right place to capture just the right moment. They’re also huge fans of each other’s work. In this conversation moderated by Louise Kiernan (a third member of the writers’ pantheon), they’ll talk about their approach to stories, the choices they make along the way, and the power of narrative to create change.

data.session_title: Extracting public records from secretive government agencies
data.speakers: Alejandra Cancino, Injustice Watch; Jason Leopold, Bloomberg News; Matt Topic, Loevy + Loevy; Parker Yesko, The New Yorker
data.description: Three reporters and their lawyer share strategies for steering your FOIAs through the bureaucratic abyss. We’ll help you craft smarter FOIAs, identify when it’s time to sue and whether you can afford to sue (usually you can!), and sharpen your wiles when a lawsuit won’t work. We’ll also show examples of what you can do with all your records when you get a bigger document dump than you ever imagined was possible!

data.session_title: Federal decisions impacting your K-12 schools
data.speakers: Ileana Najarro, Education Week; Andy Pierrotti, WANF-TV, CBS ATLANTA; Orion Rummler, The 19th*; Marina Villeneuve, Hechinger Report
data.description: Learn how changes under the Trump administration could impact schools, students, and tax dollars. This rockstar panel walks you through data and resources to explore how federal education policies are impacting immigrants, LGBTQ+ people and students with disabilities. Whether you cover local school districts, or federal education policy, we got you covered.

data.session_title: IRE Conversation: Laid off? Find your support system
data.speakers: Janelle O'Dea, Illinois Answers Project; Jonathan D. Salant, Pittsburgh Post-Gazette; Mc Nelly Torres, Independent Investigative Reporter and Editor
data.description: For anyone who has experienced a layoff, it can be so traumatic and devastating as much of our professional identity is interwoven with our personal values and purpose. It can feel like the end of the world but it is not. Come hear from those who have navigated such situations and lived to tell about it.

data.session_title: The investigative editor’s toolkit
data.speakers: Maud Beelman, Howard Center for Investigative Journalism; Len Downie Jr., ASU Walter Cronkite School; Mark Greenblatt, Howard Center for Investigative Journalism, Arizona State University; Angela Hill, Walter Cronkite School of Journalism; Lauren Mucciolo, Howard Center for Investigative Journalism at Arizona State University; Mark  Rochester, Sarasota Herald-Tribune
data.description: Join this panel of award-winning multimedia investigative journalists who will share essential tips for effective investigative editing and project management. This discussion draws on the new online curriculum from the Howard Center for Investigative Journalism at the Walter Cronkite School of Journalism and Mass Communication at ASU. The series of 12 courses covers every step of the investigative editing process, from helping your reporters hone their investigative story ideas and prepare for key interviews, to directing multimedia productions, bulletproofing, legal review and managing the stress and occasional blowback that goes with investigative journalism.

data.session_title: Tools and techniques to investigate civilian war casualties from afar
data.speakers: Yousur Al-Hlou, Freelancer; Masha Froliak, The New York Times; Rowan Philp, Global Investigative Journalism Network
data.description: This panel will describe new or newly expanded open source tools such as Airwars, OSMP, and Vantage that can measure civilian deaths and identify accountable parties, while avoiding high costs and safety risks. The panel will also highlight how on-the-ground field reporting in hostile environments can power OSINT-led investigations back in the newsroom, with examples from Ukraine and Gaza.

data.session_title: Understanding your legal rights when reporting on immigration and deportation
data.speakers: Melissa Del Bosque, Lighthouse Reports; Jennifer Nelson, Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press; Alejandro Serrano, The Texas Tribune; Gunita Singh, Reporters Committee for Freedrom of the Press
data.description:
Reporters Committee is developing a suite of resources for reporters who are covering immigration and deportation to make sure reporters know and understand their rights. This panel will give reporters and editors tools to protect themselves legally when reporting on these issues.

This session is sponsored by Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press. IRE retains control of content, including the topic and speaker selection, for all conference sessions.

data.session_title: Audio track: Juggling print and audio investigations (and how to do both, very different things at the same time)
data.speakers: Najib Aminy, Reveal; Laura Greanias, The Seattle Times; Will James, KUOW; Paige Pfleger, WPLN News and ProPublica
data.description:
Collaborations between print and audio journalists have generated chart-topping, change-making, award-winning podcasts, vastly magnifying the reach of investigative stories. 

These collaborations have the power to bring stories to life, take listeners inside the reporting process, and explore universal themes unearthed in the reporting. 

But the difference between print and audio storytelling isn't just stylistic; Sometimes these mediums have different aims altogether, and these collaborations force journalists to contend with diverging ideas of "impact" and other questions.

In this panel, you'll hear from journalists who successfully navigated these crosswinds to create print-audio collaborations that have resonated nationally. You'll walk away inspired and equipped to pitch a podcast that draws on the best of each of these mediums.

data.session_title: Broadcast track: PIVOT! New market? New station? New role? New challenges.
data.speakers: Shelby Bremer, NBC San Diego; Jatara McGee, WPXI; Charlie Specht, WGRZ-TV (NBC Buffalo)

data.session_title: Guiding your students through on-campus investigations
data.speakers: Clark Merrefield, The Journalist’s Resource at Harvard Kennedy School; Naseem Miller, The Journalist's Resource; Carmen Nobel, The Journalist's Resource (Harvard Kennedy School); Denise-Marie Ordway, The Journalist's Resource at Harvard Kennedy School
data.description: In communities where local newsrooms are shrinking and disappearing, college journalists are often the ones asking the toughest accountability questions. Join this information-packed session to discover best practices for well-informed campus reporting. This session will help student journalists (and their advisers) produce evidence-based, high-impact investigations on pressing topics like campus crime, immigration enforcement, sports stadium financing and student mental health.

data.session_title: Gun violence reporting in the Trump era
data.speakers: Abené Clayton, The Guardian; Alain Stephens, Independent journalist
data.description:
Time to get real: Media over the last 30 years is failing, complacency has lost us jobs and public trust, and harmful practices have led us to the very darkest pit of our existence in journalism. Meanwhile Americans die in the dark. It's time to break the cycle.

Gun violence coverage on our best days can often be reactive—dominated by mass shootings, political cycles, or other fleeting news moments. But as policies shift, sources disappear, and federal oversight weakens, journalists, particularly the editorial class, need to rethink how they cover guns and the communities affected by them.

This panel will explore how to find on-the-ground sources when traditional ones disappear, how federal rollbacks affect domestic violence, community safety, and policing, and how to avoid amplifying misinformation in fast-moving coverage. With media sometimes struggling to get gun reporting right in so-called “peace times,” the stakes are even higher in times of increased political instability.

data.session_title: How to report on anti-competitive behavior
data.speakers: James Grimaldi, National Catholic Reporter; David McCabe, The New York Times; Karina Montoya, Open Markets Institute; Leah Nylen, Bloomberg
data.description: From Big Tech to Main Street, companies allegedly use anti-competitive tactics to advantage themselves and hobble their rivals. Both in the U.S. and around the world, governments and people are investigating the dominant roles a handful of companies play in every industry. Hear from journalists who explain the basics of antitrust law, share tips on reporting on complaints of anticompetitive conduct and explain the government antitrust enforcement landscape. They will offer tips on how to develop sources on the competition beat, how to cover antitrust lawsuits and how to find stories from the agencies and courts tasked with enforcing the law. And finally they will offer suggestions about how to engage audiences to care about anti-competitive activities.

data.session_title: Hurricane Katrina: Lessons learned, 20 years later
data.speakers: Kathleen Johnston, Arnolt Center for Investigative Journalism at Indiana University; Halle Parker, Verite News; Jessica Williams, The Times-Picayune; Lee Zurik, Gray Media
data.description: Hurricane Katrina irrevocably changed New Orleans. The storm exposed failures in the region's federally designed levee system and changed the way local officials respond to and prepare for disasters. It rocked the city's medical community and raised questions about the ethics in emergencies. The city's recovery from the epic storm was also tainted by corruption. What lessons have local and state leaders learned from the storm and its chaotic aftermath, 20 years later?

data.session_title: Investigative reporting can save the journalism industry
data.speakers: Terry Baquet, Verite News; David Boardman, Temple University; Rhiannon Collette, Arnold Ventures; Rufus Friday, Center for Integrity in News Reporting; Marisa Kwiatkowski, Knight Foundation
data.description: We keep saying it — but for it to be true, we must make fundamental, sometimes uncomfortable changes. As Einstein warned, doing the same thing while expecting different results is madness. In this panel, funders and journalists confront the hard truth: audiences have moved on, trust has eroded and the old formulas aren't working like they used to. What are we going to do about it? This session will explore bold approaches to redefining investigative journalism with greater community agency and local impact and will discuss what it's going to take to regain trust — and achieve sustainability. The goal isn't just to survive; it's to thrive for the long term.

data.session_title: Working with whistleblowers: Past, present and future
data.speakers: Len Downie Jr., ASU Walter Cronkite School; Ross Garber, The Garber Group LLC; Dana Priest, The Washington Post; Tracee Wilkins, NBC Washington; Lisa Zycherman, Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press
data.description:
This panel will examine the past, present and future landscape of journalists’ use of confidential sources and legal risks and protections for them.

Currently, the industry is facing heightened challenges as whistleblower protections weaken; what can the past tell us about what might be ahead?

Attendees will learn about the importance of safeguarding sources and the necessity to use good old-fashioned shoe-leather reporting skills that go beyond tools, such as Signal, to protect those who risk their careers for the sake of transparency and accountability. 

You'll walk away with a better understanding of how to navigate these complexities from those who have been doing it for decades and ensure critical information flows despite the mounting pressures.

data.session_title: Audio track: Should your story be an audio documentary? Long-form narrative for national audiences
data.speakers: Rachel B. Doyle, Wondery; Kate Howard, khoward@revealnews.org; Katie Simon, NPR; Ike Sriskandarajah, This American Life
data.description: It's tempting to look for a long-form podcast in every investigation. But what are the elements of a great investigative podcast that resonate with a national audience? Editors and producers from Wondery, Reveal, This American Life and Embedded share their strategies for story selection and what their newsrooms look for in the stories they pursue.

data.session_title: Broadcast track: Me, myself & I-Team: Uplevel your investigation with or without a photographer
data.speakers: Ashley Graham, KSLA-TV; Melanie Woodrow, KGO
data.description: Small newsrooms often don't have a designated investigative reporter, but that doesn't mean they can't do great investigative work.

data.session_title: Covering immigration on any beat
data.speakers: Alfredo Corchado, Puente News Collaborative; Kristian Hernandez, The New York Times; Mary Sanchez, Independent reporter
data.description: Covering immigration can be daunting, especially for those unable to keep tabs on the ever-changing policies or latest headlines. This class is for anyone interested in covering immigration beyond the border wall. In this session, you will learn to use public datasets to help find local, state and national stories about missing migrants, work visas and court challenges to immigration policy. We will also spend some time talking about best practices for covering the immigrant community.

data.session_title: Finding stories hidden in your local government’s meeting agenda
data.speakers: Kate Huangpu, Spotlight PA; McKenna Oxenden, independent journalist; Mark  Puente, The Marshall Project
data.description: Learn tips and tricks for uncovering interesting stories and sources through local government meetings. Panelists will discuss how they uncovered compelling stories by following local government public meetings. Whether you're monitoring committee hearings in the state legislature, regularly attending your local government's city council or commissioners court, or examining how agencies oversee police departments, this session will help you identify newsworthy developments, pinpoint unique accountability stories, discover new sources, and track issues that matter to your community.

data.session_title: Reporting on mass shootings, responsibly
data.speakers: Manny Garcia, Independent journalist; Natalia Martinez, GRAY TV; Naseem Miller, The Journalist's Resource
data.description: This panel will talk about how to navigate reporting on such a large-scale tragedy. Some of the topics will include the contagion effect and how your reporting may or may not contribute to the described phenomenon. We’ll discuss what we’ve included in our coverage and what we haven’t and the process by which we came to those conclusions. Panelists will also discuss lessons learned from covering such events.

data.session_title: Reporting on stigmatized public health issues
data.speakers: Terri Langford, The Texas Tribune; Shefali  Luthra, The 19th; Amy Silverman, KJZZ-NPR
data.description: Stigma and shame often prevents treatment for public wellness issues like substance abuse, mental health, HIV/AIDS, and financial instability. This panel provides insight and best-practices when covering these stigmatized topics, as well as the importance of understanding the role of "culpable control" in storytelling and the role the media plays in access to care.

data.session_title: Spinning story gold from piles of data and docs
data.speakers: Jason Grotto, Bloomberg News; Ivana Hrynkiw, AL.com; Craig Lyons, Arnolt Center for Investigative Journalism; Taylor Mirfendereski, Independent journalist
data.description: No matter how powerful our findings from data and documents, we still need people to propel our story. We’ll show how you can dive into data, docs and other troves of records to find them. We’ll also touch on the needs of different media, showing, for example, how the right character for print might be the wrong character for TV.

data.session_title: Tracking prices and stock in the wake of economic uncertainty
data.speakers: Jennifer Burns, Bright Data; Alexander Cohen, Independent consultant
data.description:
Swift changes in policy and reactions resulted in massive price hikes, but are more coming? Industry experts also warned about impacts on the supply chain- are we on our way to empty store shelves 2.0? In this session, we’ll look at available data and resources to track this and explain how policy is impacting your audience. 

This session is sponsored by Bright Data. IRE retains control of content, including the topic and speaker selection, for all conference sessions.

data.session_title: Audio track: Driveway moments: Crafting stories that stop listeners in their tracks
data.speakers: Lauren Chooljian, New Hampshire Public Radio; Meribah Knight, Nashville Public Radio; Julieta Martinelli, Futuro Media/Futuro Studios; Paige Pfleger, WPLN News and ProPublica
data.description: Investigative journalism meets powerful storytelling in this panel designed for audio creators aiming to create those unforgettable "driveway moments"—when listeners can’t turn off the story even after arriving at their destination. Panelists will explore how to build suspense, evoke emotion, and connect with audiences on a deeply personal level while staying true to the investigative rigor. From scene-setting to pacing, attendees will gain practical strategies for turning complex investigations into gripping, memorable audio experiences.

data.session_title: Belonging under fire: In an era of backlash against diversity, equity, and inclusion efforts
data.speakers: Manny Garcia, Independent journalist; Marla Jones-Newman, The Center for Investigative Reporting; Denise-Marie Ordway, The Journalist's Resource at Harvard Kennedy School; Martin Reynolds, Maynard Institute
data.description: Belonging Under Fire: In an era of backlash against diversity, equity, and belonging efforts—both inside newsrooms and in the broader society—how can investigative journalists deepen their own internal cultures while sharpening their external reporting on systems of exclusion? This panel explores how newsrooms can stay committed to equitable hiring and retention while also elevating stories about the erosion of civil rights, attacks on marginalized communities, and systemic barriers to truth-telling. How do we sustain equitable practices in our own newsrooms amid legal, political, and institutional resistance? How do we rebuild trust with communities whose lives and truths are too often overlooked or extracted? This session explores how a deep commitment to belonging—internally and externally—can make investigative journalism more ethical, impactful, and trusted. Panelists will examine how relational journalism practices and inclusive newsroom cultures together fuel more nuanced investigations and broader democratic participation. This session is presented in partnership with the Maynard Institute.

data.session_title: Broadcast track: Visual data on deadline
data.speakers: Robin Carter, KXAS NBC 5; Ryann Grochowski Jones, ABC News & Owned Stations; Aubry Killion, WDSU-TV
data.description: Real-world examples and tools to quickly scrape data and create animated interactives for TV and Digital -- on deadline.

data.session_title: Ethically covering the impact of abortion bans
data.speakers: Ziva Branstetter & Cassandra Jaramillo, ProPublica; Eleanor Klibanoff, The Texas Tribune; Shefali  Luthra, The 19th
data.description: Twelve states have banned abortion and the federal government is eyeing unprecedented action to take those policies nationwide. On this panel, we'll help you understand how to cover the impact of these bans on real people, from women with complicated pregnancies, families who have lost loved ones, doctors facing pressure from their institutions and people who are being criminalized for performing or receiving care. Leave this panel with tangible tips on ethically approaching these thorny stories.

data.session_title: Investigating the impact of alternative energy
data.speakers: Annie Burns-Pieper, Inclusive Development International/Freelance; B. Toastie  Oaster, High Country News; Sheridan Prasso, Bloomberg
data.description: As the world races to decarbonize, demand for minerals like lithium, cobalt, and copper is surging—fueling a global mining boom. Large-scale wind and solar farms are also expanding rapidly, often with significant impacts on local communities and ecosystems. Much of this new development, both in the U.S. and globally, is happening on the lands of Indigenous Peoples and other marginalized groups, raising urgent questions about environmental justice and corporate accountability. This session will offer investigative reporters practical tools for covering the energy transition: how to connect with affected communities in the United States and internationally, trace supply chains to link harmful projects to major brands, and hold corporations and governments to account.

data.session_title: Lights! Camera! Investigation!
data.speakers: Jennifer Forsyth, The New York Times; Elizabeth Koh, The Boston Globe; J. David McSwane, ProPublica
data.description: The panelists want to invite the audience to join us in exploring the ways that novels and movies can help with structuring narrative investigations and getting past writing obstacles. The panelists will show clips of films or play snippets of recorded novels that served as creative fodder for powerful journalistic stories. The audience is encouraged to bring their own examples of movies, novels or short stories that helped in developing an investigative story. At the end we’ll compile a group list.

data.session_title: Navigating interviews on sensitive topics and in challenging settings
data.speakers: Lauren Caruba, The Dallas Morning News; Greg Fisher, CBS News 48 Hours; Kelly Garcia, Injustice Watch; Neal Morton, The Hechinger Report
data.description: Effective interviewing is crucial to impactful journalism, but these interactions can quickly become fraught in environments where sources are vulnerable or institutions are opaque. We'll teach you how to navigate these obstacles across different beats and communities, including in jails and prisons, child detention centers, indigenous communities and medical settings.

data.session_title: Unsung documents
data.speakers: James Grimaldi, National Catholic Reporter; Cheryl W. Thompson, NPR
data.description: Veteran investigative reporters reprise a classic panel and list obscure but powerful documents that anyone can use to turbocharge a project or bulk-up daily beat coverage. They also provide practical guidelines for unearthing, scrutinizing, managing and cross-referencing routine documents to unleash their full investigative power.

data.session_title: Using OpenRefine, a power tool for cleaning data
data.speakers: Christian McDonald, University of Texas at Austin
data.description:
Learn how to use OpenRefine, a powerful tool for quickly cleaning up dirty data. You'll learn about faceting, simple clustering, applying common data transformations and more.

This session is good for people with basic experience working with data. Laptops will be provided.

data.session_title: A year in local investigations: Watchdog story ideas
data.speakers: Bethany Barnes, Tampa Bay Times; Joey Cranney, The Times-Picayune | The New Orleans Advocate
data.description: Learn new and old tricks from the stories and reporters featured in the Local Matters newsletter, which spotlights a selection of great local watchdog journalism every Sunday. By showcasing a year of great work by radio, TV and newspaper reporters, we'll share tactics and tips for digging deep into stories at your local media outlet.

data.session_title: Audio track: “Getting to yes” with NPR’s Embedded: Writing the perfect podcast pitch
data.speakers: Addie Lancianese & Katie Simon, NPR; Luis Trelles, NPR’s Embedded Podcast
data.description:
You’ve been crunching the numbers and following the paper trail for years. You’re confident that your investigation is going to reveal something new, and you think it’d make a great narrative podcast series. In a crowded industry, how do you catch the ear of the people who can help you do it?

NPR’s Embedded team will help you tell the story of your story. In this interactive session, we’ll dive into the essential elements we look for in serialized podcasts, teaching you how to identify compelling characters, formulate sticky questions and create narrative momentum. Along the way, you’ll learn how to pitch Embedded — NPR’s home for ambitious, deeply reported documentary series.

data.session_title: Broadcast track: Art of the interview
data.speakers: Scott Friedman, NBC 5 Dallas-Fort Worth; Andy Pierrotti, WANF-TV, CBS ATLANTA; Darcy Spears, KTNV (ABC Las Vegas)
data.description: How to get the best story and emotion from your interviewee.

data.session_title: How to write character-driven features about climate change and the environment
data.speakers: Adam Mahoney, Capital B; Naveena Sadasivam & John Thomason, Grist; Boyce Upholt, freelance writer
data.description: There may be no topic in contemporary journalism more dauntingly abstract than climate change: Carbon emissions are invisible and impersonal, and even though their consequences are increasingly apparent in the environment around us, the link between those effects and human action is frustratingly opaque. However, the scale of the challenge requires journalists to find ways to connect this seemingly overwhelming process to recognizable human dilemmas and conflicts. This panel discusses the ways that reporters can center human (and non-human) drama to better illuminate contemporary environmental dilemmas.

data.session_title: Leveraging AI to enhance political accountability
data.speakers: Matt DeFour, Wisconsin Watch; Justen Fox, American Journalism Project; Chandran Sankaran & Robyn Sundlee, Gigafact
