data.description: How can AI be used to hold politicians accountable for their promises, claims and speech? This session will share the findings of a landscape study on how AI is being used by journalists around the country today. We will demonstrate one of the tools that has been leveraged by Wisconsin Watch and others—Gigafact Parser, a shared database for journalists that summarizes and analyzes audio and video records of politicians’ speeches. Attendees can expect to learn about Parser and other cutting-edge tools, hear case studies for their use, and get a better understanding of the state of AI in journalism.

data.session_title: Me Too isn’t over: Lessons from both sides of sexual harassment and violence investigations
data.speakers: Cara Kelly & Olivia Messer & Leslie Rangel, The Barbed Wire
data.description: What have we learned since the Me Too movement reached a zenith in 2017? For starters, sexual misconduct is everywhere (including the journalism industry) and requires diligent and trauma-informed reporting. This panel will cover hard-learned lessons from eight years of reporting and editing sexual misconduct investigations — and from unexpectedly finding ourselves as sources on the other side. We’ll cover the ways we still get this reporting wrong, from pushing traumatized sources too hard to go on-record, to discounting nontraditional records like journal entries or social media messages, to the he-said-she-said of it all. And, we’ll finally put to rest the notion that lived experience is a disqualifier for journalists covering this topic.

data.session_title: SHOWCASE: Finding inspiration in the face of change
data.speakers: Keri Blakinger, Houston Chronicle; Len Downie Jr., ASU Walter Cronkite School; David Fahrenthold, The New York Times; Kevin Merida, ; Lea Thompson, Retired - NBC News
data.description: The journalism industry has faced a tremendous amount of challenges and changes. How does investigative journalism persevere — and grow?

data.session_title: Strategies for investigating offshore companies
data.speakers: John Dell'Osso, Platform to Protect Whistleblowers in Africa; Douglas Gillison, Reuters
data.description:
This hands-on session will show you how to use publicly available information to identify who owns and benefits from companies that are set up in jurisdictions with comprehensive corporate secrecy. In an era of increasing transnational corruption, being able to publicly expose who is behind a company and the deals in which they participate will be critical for accountability journalism. While having a leak or an inside source that exposes this information would be ideal, this is not something we can rely on and there are other approaches. This training will draw from years of experience piercing the veil around such secretive companies.

This session is good for all levels! Attendees will need to bring their own laptops (preferably no tablets) for the training.

data.session_title: Audio track: Evolving narratives in audio storytelling about crime
data.speakers: Nicole Dungca, The Washington Post; Sukey Lewis, KQED; Julieta Martinelli, Futuro Media/Futuro Studios; Parker Yesko, The New Yorker
data.description: Journalists hate the term "true crime." But true crime podcasts have captivated audiences, and the genre is evolving beyond its traditional confines. This panel explores how investigative journalists and storytellers are redefining true crime by focusing on systemic issues, deeper narratives and ethical storytelling. Panelists will share their experiences crafting compelling audio that goes beyond "whodunit," balancing audience engagement with sensitivity, accuracy and accountability. Attendees will gain insights into innovative reporting techniques, narrative structure and the ethical dilemmas of audio storytelling in this increasingly popular medium.

data.session_title: Broadcast track: Secrets for success: IRE Award winners show how to elevate your investigation
data.speakers: Amy Davis, KPRC 2 News; Melissa Del Bosque & Jack Sapoch, Lighthouse Reports; Jeremy Finley, WSMV-TV; Andrea Slaydon, KPRC-TV, NBC Houston
data.description: Deep Dive for IRE Award Winners - Video

data.session_title: Crowdsourcing data for your next investigation
data.speakers: Cassandra Garibay, ProPublica; Sergio Olmos, CalMatters; Leon Yin, Bloomberg News
data.description:
This panel will showcase three investigations built around crowdsourced data, with an emphasis on the tools that you can use for your next big story. 

We will share Bloomberg News' reporting on how Uber and Lyft “locked out” drivers from work in order to game the city’s minimum wage law. Bloomberg News built an automated WhatsApp tipline that circulated to drivers across New York City to crowdsource over 7,000 screenshots of lockouts from nearly 900 drivers. 

Reporters will discuss using social media videos to trawl for tips on immigrant raids and building intake forums to standardize tips from sources.

We will share tips on how to maximize participation from sources, validate messy user-submitted data, and how to combine shoe-leather reporting with the affordances of automation.

data.session_title: Deep dive: Two friends on what they’ve learned along the way
data.speakers: Ken Armstrong, Bloomberg News; Ginger Thompson, ProPublica
data.description: Ginger Thompson and Ken Armstrong go way back. Both longtime investigative journalists, their resumes include Pulitzers, Peabodys, Polks. They worked together at ProPublica. And the Chicago Tribune. And, four decades ago, they worked together at their college newspaper, the Purdue Exponent. (Their staff was quite something. The cartoonist went on to co-write and co-direct Pixar’s “Up.”) They’ll talk craft, lessons learned, how to do stories that make a difference, how to grow and keep growing—and what they owe to their college paper.

data.session_title: How student journalists are leading real-world investigative reporting across the U.S.
data.speakers: Lee Ann Anderson, University of Florida; Christopher Drew, Louisiana State University; Sarah Gamard, Center for Community News; Rick Hirsch, University of Florida College of Journalism and Communications
data.description: This panel will showcase student-led investigative reporting with real-world impact, from holding some of the most powerful in the state accountable to uncovering new information about unsolved civil rights murders. Faculty and students involved in this work will talk about the do's and don'ts of relying on students to lead investigative work, as well as what they are actually able to accomplish.

data.session_title: How to background people in an hour
data.speakers: Michael Biesecker, Associated Press; Jennifer Gollan, San Francisco Chronicle ; Yami Virgin, KABB WOAI
data.description: Whether covering a mass shooting or a political scandal, reporters need to know how to thoroughly and quickly background people and companies involved in breaking news events and long-term investigations. In this panel, journalists will share concrete tips on how to mine social media accounts, maximize Nexis searches, unearth public records, find friends and relatives and turn hunches into distinctive stories.

data.session_title: Staying alive: Inside secrets on how to thrive through job moves, layoffs and newsroom drama
data.speakers: Daphne Duret, The Marshall Project; Larry Graham, The Diversity Pledge Institute
data.description: In this discussion and Q&A, Larry Graham will share some of his experiences placing journalists in some of the top newsrooms in the country and offer insights on topics like negotiating severance, navigating career pivots, making the most out of a job or promotion offer and even leveraging multiple offers for the best deal possible. Whether you've just been fired, laid off, or you’re interested in taking the next step in your career, these are answers you won’t hear anywhere else.

data.session_title: Writing short: Narratives don't have to be long!
data.speakers: Walt Bogdanich, The New York Times; Jenifer McKim, GBH News; Robbie Morganfield, Ida B. Wells Society for Investigative Reporting
data.description: Well-crafted narratives help engage readers in investigative reports that convey complex information. Compelling narratives don't need to be 4,000 + words.  We explain what you need -- and don't need -- to tell a story in fewer words.

data.session_title: Audio track: Editing the investigative podcast
data.speakers: Kate Howard, khoward@revealnews.org; Brendan McCarthy, The Boston Globe; Peniley Ramírez, Futuro Media
data.description: Experienced editors share their best tips on deciding when to pursue long-form audio stories, developing story arcs that grip listeners and guiding your team through creating a revelatory and impactful podcast.

data.session_title: Automating your beat
data.speakers: Jill Castellano, The Marshall Project
data.description:
Have you ever encountered a document that's difficult to search or a collection of documents containing tables that you want to extract and analyze? Join this session to learn how you can extract data from handwritten reports and tables buried in PDFs, uncover patterns in extensive document sets using regular expressions and AI tools, convert emails into searchable PDFs, monitor local government websites for real-time changes and much more. 

This session is good for beginners and people interested in extracting data from documents. Attendees will need to bring their own laptops (preferably no tablets) for the training.

data.session_title: Broadcast track: AI AI AI: Three fakes and a real
data.speakers: Jamie Grey, InvestigateTV; Andrew Lehren, Craig Newmark Graduate School of Journalism at CUNY; Rhona Tarrant, CBS News
data.description: Real life examples to protect you from reporting (or sharing) misinformation.

data.session_title: Covering economic development incentives: What it really means to give companies public dollars
data.speakers: Paula Gardner, Bridge Michigan; Arlene Martinez, Good Jobs First; J. Dale Shoemaker, Investigative Post
data.description: When the Washington Post reported Elon Musk's companies have received at least $38 billion in economic development subsidies, grants, and loans, it provoked some uproar in light of Musk's allegations of government overspending. But Musk is just one of many CEOs who have benefited from large subsidy packages given in the name of economic development. In this session, learn how to find out what companies are getting incentives (with the help of Good Jobs First's Subsidy Tracker and other public financial documents), the impact to public budgets, how to make sense of "economic impact" reports, and how to dig into deals to be able to answer - are the deals, which involve turning over public money to private companies, worth it?

data.session_title: Covering science in the political spotlight
data.speakers: Jen Christensen, CNN and NLGJA; Elena Renken, SciLine; Lisa Song, ProPublica; Alison Young, Independent journalist
data.description: In the fast-changing policy landscape of 2025, government officials have distanced scientific evidence from political decision-making and frequently ignored scientific consensus. Misleading claims about issues ranging from fluoridating water to vaccine safety to climate change impacts are drawing scientific evidence into the spotlight, and this controversy warrants deeper reporting to get to the gist of the evidence. Speakers will explore how they've investigated science at the center of political controversy, and give concrete advice on how to cut through political cross-talk with evidence, unearth the interests at play in these controversies, and portray complex evidence clearly for their audiences.

data.session_title: Deep dive: Dealing with pushback
data.speakers: Lauren Chooljian, New Hampshire Public Radio; David Enrich, The New York Times
data.description: David Enrich’s new book, “Murder the Truth,” details how the powerful—billionaires, politicians, corporations—use litigation and threats to stifle reporting that could hold them accountable. Enrich will talk with Lauren Chooljian, to which a chapter of his book is devoted. Chooljian was subjected to vandalism and threats while investigating sexual misconduct; four men were ultimately convicted of criminal charges in connection with a campaign to silence her station’s work. They’ll discuss the intimidation tactics being used against journalists, and what reporters and editors (and their lawyers) can do when faced with them.

data.session_title: How to investigate digital threats
data.speakers: Anna Massoglia, Influence Brief; Craig Silverman, Indicator
data.description: How to investigate digital threats (disinformation campaigns, online scams, harassment, and anonymous hate speech websites), and expose the bad actors behind them. In this panel, leading media manipulation journalists will share effective tips and easy-to-use tools to expose this sinister cyber world.

data.session_title: Investigating DOGE
data.speakers: Sophie Alexander, Bloomberg News; Sophia Cai, Politico; David Fahrenthold, The New York Times; Jenna McLaughlin, NPR; Annie Waldman, ProPublica
data.description: Elon Musk has said that the Department of Government Efficiency, also known as DOGE, is a transparent cost-cutting government initiative, but its inner workings have largely been opaque. What is DOGE? Who is DOGE? These journalists have been working to uncover the actions of the federal initiative, as well as its impact, and will share tips on how national, local and beat reporters can cover DOGE.

data.session_title: Master class: Under pressure: Real life in real time with breaking news
data.speakers: Stephen Stock, WVUE Gray TV
data.description:
One of the hottest sessions at every IRE Conference! How would you and your newsroom fare in digging out little-known facts and information under the pressure of a breaking news deadline? One of the best ways to get better is to practice.

This is a real-life scenario where you can learn to break news without leaving your computer. The skills learned in this session can also be used for turning daily general assignment stories when there’s not breaking news. This session regularly fills up and the tipsheet that comes with it is in high demand. If you're interested, get there early to get a seat.

Preregistration is required and seating is limited.

data.session_title: What the Real Housewives can teach you about investigative journalism
data.speakers: Cary Aspinwall, The Marshall Project; Ko Bragg, ; Marissa Evans, Investigative Project on Race and Equity; Arionne Nettles, Florida A&M University
data.description: What can we learn about investigative reporting from the Real Housewives franchise? Plenty. Preparing for accountability interviews, recognizing and dismantling bias in storytelling/narrative perspective — and how to bring the receipts. Get ready for the reunion!

data.session_title: Audio track: Carving out space for local audio investigations
data.speakers: Alex Hall, KQED Public Radio; Anna King, Northwest Public Broadcasting; Paige Pfleger, WPLN News and ProPublica; Camille Phillips, Texas Public Radio
data.description: When you’re a reporter in a small, local newsroom it can be hard to find time to work on investigative projects. On this panel, four local audio reporters with experience on investigative projects will talk about how they managed to carve out space and energy to chip away at investigations while juggling daily news and still being present in their newsrooms. This panel will be helpful for any local reporter – in audio, or not! -  who wants to make the jump into investigative journalism.

data.session_title: Broadcast track: Lightning Talks
data.speakers: Dawn Clapperton, NBC6 South Florida; Greg Fisher, CBS News 48 Hours; Rick Gevers, Rick Gevers & Associates; Charlie McLravy, Inside Edition; Nate Morabito, WCNC Charlotte; Leslie Rangel, The Barbed Wire; Dorothy Tucker, WBBM-TV; Katie Wilcox, 12News
data.description:
Come to this session to hear rapid-fire lecture from broadcast pros. Moderated by Charlie McLravy; talks will include:
1 Jailhouse Interviews
2 How to pitch your investigative story to your managers
3 Check Your Bias: Tools for Cultural Competency
4 Tips for Negotiating your new contract 
5 How to win over your Promotions Team - and why it matters
6 Don't Miss the Moment
7  Don't forget to decompress! (focus on reporter mental health)

data.session_title: Campus wars: Tools & techniques to investigate the battle over higher ed
data.speakers: Torsheta Jackson, Mississippi Free Press; Vimal Patel, The New York Times; Jessica Priest, The Texas Tribune; Joe Stephens, Princeton University
data.description: Trump and his aides are withholding huge sums of money and barring international students from college campuses, aiming to shift the ideological tilt of higher education. Colleges are fighting back in court and in Congress. Documents, data and source work reveal what’s really going on in the trenches.

data.session_title: Finding and using historical documents in investigative stories
data.speakers: Steve Eder & Cam Rodriguez, The New York Times; Alexia Fernández Campbell, Bloomberg Industry Group; Nadia Hamdan, Center for Investigative Reporting; Mc Nelly Torres, Independent Investigative Reporter and Editor
data.description: Methods from the practices of archivists, librarians, and historians can help journalists surface and use historical documents. In this session, learn about incorporating history into deep-dive stories.

data.session_title: International journalists, American press freedom and what's happening now
data.speakers: Iram Abbasi, Multimedia journalist; Mariana Belloso, Inter-American Press Association / Latin American Network for Journalism in Exile; Kathy Jones, Committee to Protect Journalists; Louise Kiernan, Northwestern University; Lisa Zycherman, Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press
data.description: On this panel, two international journalists and two press freedom experts will discuss the rapidly increasing threats to independent journalism and how reporters can protect themselves physically, mentally, and digitally, as well as what journalists from the United States can learn from their international counterparts who have worked under repressive and chaotic regimes.

data.session_title: Policing by algorithm: Covering AI in law enforcement
data.speakers: Jamiles Lartey, The Marshall Project; Beryl Lipton, Electronic Frontier Foundation; Doug  MacMillan, The Washington Post; Hannah  Riley Fernandez, Center for Just Journalism
data.description: AI is rapidly reshaping policing—sometimes in ways even police themselves don't fully understand. From AI-powered facial recognition leading to wrongful arrests to automated systems drafting police reports, these technologies raise urgent questions about accuracy, bias, and accountability. This panel brings together investigative journalists and researchers who have exposed the risks and real-world consequences of AI in policing. Panelists will offer a behind-the-scenes look at how their investigations came together, and insights/tips for journalists interested in doing this reporting in their own communities.

data.session_title: Regular expressions: Puzzling out clean data
data.speakers: Christian McDonald, University of Texas at Austin
data.description:
Regular expressions are a pattern-matching syntax used in spreadsheets and programming languages, providing a powerful skill to slice, dice and clean up dirty data. They may look intimidating, but they are really just puzzles. We'll learn the fundamentals of "regex" to save you time cleaning your next batch of data.
 
This session is good for: People who have ever done more than one search/replace actions to clean a data set, or had to split an address, or otherwise want to conquer their fears of regex. Bring your own laptop. We’ll just be using a browser for this hands-on lesson.

data.session_title: Reporting on corporate-driven health crises
data.speakers: Ben Hallman, The Examination; Christina Jewett, The New York Times; Sharon Lerner, ProPublica; Zoya Teirstein, Grist
data.description: From ultra-processed foods and cigarettes to PFAS and air pollution: commercial products and processes are major contributors to disease, death and economic harm. We will share practical approaches to covering industry-driven health crises, with an emphasis on connecting those stories to real people in harm’s way. Topics to include: how industry shapes health narratives, reporting on emerging threats, humanizing climate coverage and – yes – how to approach health reporting in an era of MAHA and regulatory layoffs. You will not leave empty-handed: we will point you to sources, data, story ideas, and more!

data.session_title: Telling the human story behind the investigation: Crafting a stand-alone narrative within a global reporting project
data.speakers: Lynette Clemetson, University of Michigan; Nicole Sadek, International Consortium of Investigative Journalists
data.description:
In this conversation with 2025 Livingston Award winner for international reporting Nicole Sadek, we’ll explore how to craft a powerful stand-alone narrative that deepens and contextualizes the broader themes of a collaborative investigative series. 

When the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists, the nonprofit that led the Panama Papers investigation, partnered with 26 media outlets to expose how Western oil companies bypassed laws and ethics to profit from the Kazakhstan-Russia pipeline, reporter Nicole Sadek was asked to continue her team’s research into Berezovka — a now-abandoned village in Kazakhstan ravaged by toxic exposure. She connected with former residents, environmental advocates, and officials from the World Bank and United Nations, and traveled to the village to illuminate the serious health issues suffered by its former residents and the underreported human costs of global industry.

This session is sponsored by the Wallace House Center for Journalists. IRE retains control of content, including the topic and speaker selection, for all conference sessions.

data.session_title: International collaborations for global investigative impact
data.speakers: Amruta Byatnal, Thomson Reuters Foundation/Context; Melissa Del Bosque, Lighthouse Reports; Reed Richardson, Global Investigative Journalism Network; Maryam Saleh, Rest of World
data.description: International investigations are made stronger by partnerships and collaborations that are able to drawn on strengths of different individuals and newsrooms. But these projects can also be fraught with challenges - who owns the investigative tools, who does the writing, whose editing works best? This panel will discuss how to make global investigations work for everyone by sharing examples of what has worked and what hasn’t, and highlighting best practices.

data.session_title: Resilience by design: Mindset interventions for journalists
data.speakers: Aaron  Glantz, Stanford University; Parul Somani, Mindset coach
data.description: Investigative journalist and Stanford fellow Aaron Glantz and mindset coach Parul Somani present a groundbreaking approach to resilience, inspired by successful “cancer mindset” interventions. Learn how reframing adversity can help journalists adapt, build community, and thrive in tough times. Attendees will leave with practical self-reflection prompts and tools to strengthen their mental health so they leave IRE empowered to prevail in tough times ahead.

data.session_title: The art of fact-checking
data.speakers: Ethan Corey, The Appeal; Mariam Elba, ProPublica; Nina Zweig, Type Investigations
data.description: Many newsrooms don’t spend resources on fact-checking, leaving reporters exposed to potential corrections, public embarrassment, or even litigation. Given the current political climate and the new administration’s aggressive stance toward watchdog journalism, it’s more important than ever to learn how to vet your own work and protect yourself. This session, featuring three longtime investigative researchers, will teach reporters how to approach their reporting with an eye toward fact-checking.

data.session_title: Demystifying crime data: Learning the tools to effectively evaluate crime trends
data.speakers: Jeff Asher, AH Datalytics
data.description: Crime data can be challenging to acquire, analyze, and communicate even in the best of circumstances. In this session, Jeff Asher will discuss the major pitfalls and struggles to effectively incorporating crime data into understanding crime at the local, state, and national levels while accounting for the uncertainty of working with imperfect information. This session will also include discussion of the tools any journalist can use to better use crime data in their reporting.

data.session_title: Developing curriculum for the next generation of journalists
data.speakers: Maud Beelman, Howard Center for Investigative Journalism; Christopher Drew, Louisiana State University; Angela Hill, Walter Cronkite School of Journalism; Jennifer LaFleur, UC Berkeley Graduate School of Journalism; Andrew Lehren, Craig Newmark Graduate School of Journalism at CUNY
data.description: While we often hear that youth is wasted on the young, educators know that it's a two-way street in how we can learn from who we teach. We'll discuss what are our non-negotiables in journalism education and where perhaps we should reframe our thinking in order to prepare the next generation of journalists to do meaningful work with impact and cope with the tumult of the newsroom industry.

data.session_title: Everything you want to know about tracking political influence and money in politics
data.speakers: Soorin Kim, ABC News; Robert Maguire, Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington (CREW); Anna Massoglia, Influence Brief
data.description: For anyone looking to dive into the world of money in politics, this session is for you! Whether it's corporate influence campaigns, dark money, foreign lobbying or anything in between, we've tracked it. The three panelists are OpenSecrets alumni with at least 30 years of collective experience working with money-in-politics data, documents and other information crucial to reporting on how special interest groups influence policy and shape laws and regulations at the state and federal level. We'll walk through the basics for where to find information and leave plenty of time for questions afterward.

data.session_title: Organizing your investigation
data.speakers: Daniela Ibarra, KSAT; Katey Rusch, Investigative Reporting Program
data.description: Whether you use Post-Its, a white board, a spreadsheet or an old-fashioned yellow pad, keeping your head above a flood of information is crucial to your investigation’s success. This session will tap examples for techniques to navigate the key phases of organizing your story in any medium: managing material; pruning and pivoting; and visualizing the story.

data.session_title: The lasting effects of extreme weather
data.speakers: Keely Arthur, WRAL NEWS; Justin Garcia, Tampa Bay Times; Sam Karlin, The Times-Picayune | The New Orleans Advocate; Gordon Russell, The Boston Globe
data.description: Whether it’s flooding, rising seas or drought, wildfire or uncertain drinking water supplies, each city and state is experiencing the effects of climate change in its own way. But where do you find climate data and narratives, and what’s the best way to tell your city’s climate story? This panel will bring together some of the best reporters and communicators on the climate/weather beat to discuss how they use data, science and lived experience of their sources on the ground as the foundation for reporting that reveals the science behind climate impacts and the people affected.
